ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION
ORDINANCE
(Amending legislation)


    1. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will consider introducing legislation to amend the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance (a) by extending the applicability of the Ordinance to all categories of employees earning $750 or less per month; and (b) by increasing the numbers of months of earnings and the maximum amounts prescribed for compensation in section 8 of the Ordinance where injury sustained results in the death or in permanent total disablement of the employee.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, manual workers are eligible for workmen's compensation under the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance, 1954, irrespective of the amount of their monthly earnings. It is only in respect of non-manual workers that the ceiling of $400 earnings per month is fixed so that non-manual workers earning more than $400 per month will not be eligible for workmen's compensation.

    If the Ordinance is amended in the manner suggested by the Member for Kallang, it would have the effect of denying workmen's compensation for manual workers should their earnings exceed $750 per month. As for non-manual workers, statistics for the 11 months of January to November 1969 show that the number of non-manual workers who were paid workmen's compensation was 14 out of a total of 7,952. This works out to 0.17 per cent, the rest being all manual workers. Raising the eligibility of non-manual workers for claims of workmen's compensation would, therefore, have little

Column: 300

or no practical effect since it is well known that manual workers are exposed to greater risks to their personal safety in the course of their employment than non-manual workers.

    Under section 8 of the Ordinance, the amount of workmen's compensation for victims of accidents resulting in death is calculated on 36 months of their monthly earnings or $7,200 whichever is the less. Where the victim is permanently disabled, the workmen's compensation is calculated on 48 months of his monthly earnings or $9,600 whichever is the less. The maximum payable for death or permanent disablement of the employee is based on an earning of $200 per month. This figure is above the average monthly earnings of workers in Singapore which, according to a sample survey made in 1968, amounted to $180.60 per month. Amending legislation will be made to revise the scales of benefits should the average monthly earnings of workers in Singapore exceed $200.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Does the Parliamentary Secretary value a man's life only at $7,200 or 36 months' wages?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think that is laid down as compensation; that is, a man's life-span of work expected of him. But I am sure, if the Member has any suggestion to make, we will be very glad to receive it.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Does the Parliamentary Secretary not believe that the estate of a deceased person stands a better chance of being awarded more damages by the High Court than the award of $7,200 under the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, depending on the individual case, I am sure the deceased's family is at liberty to seek workmen's compensation or to seek redress in the High Court.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree with me that a workman would get more

Column: 301

compensation from damages by the High Court if he were to die in a road accident than in a factory or at a work site?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, that is a hypothetical question. I do not think I am in a position to answer that.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary said just now that if the average worker in Singapore should get $200 a month, then he would take steps to amend the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance. But is not the per capita income of a worker over $200?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: No, Sir. It can be seen from page 49 of the 1968 Report of the Ministry of Labour, where there is a report of a sample survey, that the average monthly income was $180.60.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not consider it expedient to extend the definition of "workman" to all classes and categories of workers irrespective of whether they perform manual or technical work?

    Mr Speaker: I think that question was answered in the Parliamentary Secretary's principal answer.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I underline the word "technical".

    Mr Speaker: Has the Parliamentary Secretary anything to add?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I do not think I have anything to add to that.

LABOUR SHORTAGE
(Survey of situation in Singapore)


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (a) whether there is a shortage of skilled, semi-skilled and unskilled labour in Singapore recently due to the Government's policy of rapid industrialisation; (b) what steps have been taken or are being taken to remedy the situation; and (c) if he will consider an overall survey to ascertain the actual situation.

Column: 302



    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the categories and numbers of persons currently registered for employment in the Employment Exchange, there appears to be a shortage of skilled labour and to a lesser extent semiskilled labour in Singapore. However, there is no shortage of unskilled labour. Out of a total of 52,115 persons registered for employment at the Employment Exchange as on 30th November, 1969, 1,475 were registered as skilled workers, 3,259 as semi-skilled workers and 28,854 as unskilled workers. The remaining persons were registered as commercial and domestic workers.

    The steps taken by the Government to meet the immediate shortage of skilled workers include (i) encouragement to industrial concerns to undertake their own training programmes to meet their demands for skilled workers; (ii) permission for industrial concerns to bring in skilled labour from outside Singapore; (iii) provision of special courses to upgrade and retrain workers in the Vocational Institutes and the Industrial Training Centres by way of day-release and evening classes. To meet the requirements of industries for skilled personnel on a long-term basis, Government has taken measures to restructure the educational system so that there will be an increasing number of school-leavers in the coming years with vocational and technical training.

    From time to time, various organisations, including the Ministry of Labour, the National Productivity Centre, the Technical Education Department of the Ministry of Education, and the Economic Research Centre of the University of Singapore, have carried out their own surveys to ascertain the manpower requirements in certain specific areas or industries. At the moment, the question of an overall survey is not an urgent one. If at some future date the situation demands it, Government will consider making an overall survey to ascertain the skilled manpower requirements of Singapore.

PROFESSIONAL EMPLOYMENT
PASSES
(Particulars of applications)


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Defence (a) how many non-citizens have applied for Professional Employment Passes from August, 1968, up to the latest convenient date; (b) how many applications were approved; and (c) the reasons for rejecting the other applications.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the period August 1968 to November 1969, 7,051 applications were received from non-citizens for professional visit passes and employment passes. The number of applications included new applications and applications for extension. During the same period, 6,911 applications were approved. The number approved included some applications submitted before August 1968 and finalised after 1st August, 1968. A total of 508 applications were rejected during the same period. The rejections also included some applications submitted before August 1968 and finalised after 1st August, 1968.

    The reasons for rejecting the applications are as follows:

    (1) If local citizens with similar qualifications and experience were considered available to take over the jobs applied for.

    (2) Applicants who were considered of little or no appreciable economic benefit to Singapore; and

    (3) Security objections.

LIVE WORMS FOR FANCY FISH


    4. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) if he is aware that fancy fish breeders and hobbyists are having difficulty in obtaining live worms from local sources since the recent anti-mosquito campaign was started; and (b) if he will instruct the Primary Production Department to undertake the breeding of worms under controlled conditions to restore the local supply of live

Column: 304

worms to meet the requirements of our fancy fish breeders and hobbyists, in view of the export earning capacity of fancy fish.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the current shortage of worms is due not so much to the anti-mosquito campaign but rather to the rapid increase in the demand for worms as more and more people breed fancy fish either for their own enjoyment or for export.

    The Primary Production Department has been conducting experiments in tubi-fex worm cultivation since 1967. Successful techniques have been evolved to enable fancy fish breeders to produce their own worms. The techniques have been taught to interested parties and demonstration units have been set up at Lim Chu Kang and Sembawang veterinary centres. In fact, many aquarium fish hobbyists and exporters are now producing tubi-fex worms on their own. Those who are interested should apply to the Primary Production Department for a demonstration of the technique of worm production.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister encourage further the breeding of worms so that fish breeders and hobbyists will not find it difficult to get worms?

    Mr Barker: The Primary Production Department will encourage the breeding of worms. For those who do not know how to breed them, the Department will be only too pleased to give them a demonstration of the technique of tubi-fex worm production.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker. Sir, is the Minister aware that worms are now being imported from across the Causeway?

    Mr Barker: Yes, and I do not see any objection to such imports. We have in the past imported worms even from Japan.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the Minister give us some assurance that we will be self-sufficient in worms?

Column: 305



    Mr Barker: I cannot give the Member that assurance. The only assurance I can give is that the Primary Production Department itself, whilst not producing worms on its own, is prepared to show fish hobbyists how they can go about producing worms.

FLOODS
(Preventive measures)


    5. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development, in view of the serious floods in early December, 1969, whether Government has any effective plans to prevent those serious floods from recurring.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the floods on 10th December last were caused by unprecedented heavy rains coinciding with a high spring tide. Nothing can be done to prevent rainfall or to alter the movement of tides. However, our drainage system can be improved. But finance is the limiting factor. We can construct a drainage system augmented by huge pumping stations that will meet all eventualities, but this will be extremely costly and difficult to justify. Like all public work projects, priorities have to be decided.

    Over the last few years, several drainage and flood alleviation schemes have been approved. Some of these have been completed, whilst others are still under construction. The following schemes are now under construction:

    (1) The Bukit Timah Flood Alleviation Scheme, Phase 1, which is the cutting of a diversion canal to channel water from the upper Bukit Timah catchment area to Ulu Pandan canal. The scheme is expected to be completed by the end of next year and the cost will be in the region of $6� million.

    (2) The urban renewal drainage scheme - the New Bridge Road outlet drain and Peng Siang Quay outlet drain. Concrete lining and realignment of both drains is being done. Completion date is May 1970 and the cost is $1 million.

    (3) The Sungei Kallang improvement scheme, which consists of the realignment and widening of the river from

Column: 306

Braddell Road to Thomson Road, including Potong Pasir and Lorong Chuan, costing $� million.

    (4) Kampong Kembangan and Siglap improvement scheme. Work is being done on the improvement of subsidiary drains in the Kampong Kembangan area which lead into the Siglap Canal at a cost of $150,000.

    (5) Sungei Whampoa lining. Concrete lining of Sungei Whampoa is expected to be completed in four months' time at a cost of $� million.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in addition, all flood alleviation and drainage plans are being reassessed and, finance permitting, proposals for new drainage schemes will be implemented in the future that will lessen the severity of floods. We could not altogether avoid the flooding that was caused by the unprecedented 16.9 inches of rainfall in 24 hours on the 10th of December coinciding with a high spring tide of 10 feet 1 inch.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, apart from the various schemes mentioned by the Minister, what are the flood alleviation schemes that have been completed and where are these schemes situated?

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the most recently completed one was the Pelton Canal scheme which was the lining of Pelton Canal through MacPherson Estate completed in May this year at a cost of $� million. The Alexandra Canal lining was completed in 1968 at a cost of $2 million. The Geylang Canal widening and lining was completed in 1968 at a cost of $1.2 million. The Tampines Road Canal improvement was completed in 1967 at a cost of $� million. The Orchard Road Canal lining was completed in 1964 at a cost of $� million.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, apart from these completed schemes and in view of the serious flood recently, can the Minister inform the House of other proposed flood alleviation schemes and when these will be started?

Column: 307



    Mr Barker: Sir, the biggest scheme which has not yet received approval is the second phase of the Bukit Timah flood alleviation scheme to cut a new canal from the 3� milestone Bukit Timah Road through Whitley Road and Thomson Road along part of Sungei Whampoa to join up with Sungei Kallang at Kallang Basin. The estimated cost is $7� million.

    The next scheme is at Potong Pasir and Lorong Chuan valley. This is a rather low-lying area. We could widen Sungei Kallang and realign and improve its subsidiary drains. We could even construct a storage reservoir in Lorong Chuan valley. But all this would cost $5� million.

    There are some smaller projects. For instance, Geylang Serai is a very low-lying area and some parts of it are below high tide level. There is a scheme which is being considered to provide adequate concrete-lined canals in Geylang Serai. This will cost about $300,000. Other smaller schemes are the improvement and lining of Rochore Canal costing about $1 million, the provision of adequate canals, and the raising of the level of the roads in the Boon Tat Street area which would cost about $� million.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister say whether there is any flood alleviation scheme for Changi, especially in the Koh Sek Lim Road area which was very badly hit by the recent floods?

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, officials from the Public Works Department and the Public Utilities Board are reconsidering the drainage plans for the Bedok/Changi area; we are thinking of building a reservoir where the Housing and Development Board is digging earth to reclaim the east coast. We may build this reservoir both as a catchment area against floods and to catch the Water during floods. Alternatively, if the water is not very polluted, we can use it as an additional store for our water supply. The matter is receiving the consideration of officials and a decision will be made soon.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, arising out of the question of floods, what is the Government's policy in regard to the construction of temporary unauthorised shacks or huts by the victims in the recent floods? Is the Government going to allow this?

    Mr Barker: Without any hesitation, I would say yes to the Member for Bras Basah. People who have suffered and lost their homes either completely or partly can surely repair or rebuild and have a roof over their heads without fearing prosecution from the Chief Building Surveyor. On the other hand, of course, we must watch the position to see that others who have not suffered from the floods do not take the opportunity to erect unauthorised houses.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, has the Government any plans to carry out flood alleviation schemes in Sembawang Constituency? Certain areas in Sembawang were affected by the recent floods and had water as high as four feet. Some roads have been eroded by the flood waters. Will the Government take immediate steps to repair these roads?

    Mr Barker: Immediate steps are being taken to repair the roads which have been spoilt as a result of the floods. But this supplementary question is really in connection with the second question of the Member for Sembawang.

    As to floods in Sembawang, I think the Member will agree with me that this was the first time the floods affected Sembawang. Frankly, we have no concrete plans for alleviating floods in Sembawang. But as I said in the last sentence of my reply, our whole flood alleviation measures are being reconsidered with a view to alleviating floods which may occur as a result of either heavy rains for many hours or high tides or both.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister said that Sembawang was affected by the floods for the first time. I hope it will not happen again there.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in regard to the recent floods, the damage done was very serious. Some rich people had their cars totally submerged in the flood and these were completely damaged. Some people were killed and others injured. Damage to property was extensive.

    Just now the Minister mentioned big flood alleviation projects coming up. That is good news. But, from my point of view, projects are projects. In this connection, we must learn from our past experience in building flats and houses. We have been very speedy in putting up houses and flats. Therefore, we should be equally speedy in carrying out these flood alleviation schemes.

    For example, the Ulu Pandan scheme has been going on for the last few years. I paid visits to the work site a few times, but there were no men working on the scheme. Ulu Pandan Road is a very important main trunk road which will connect Singapore with Malaysia and even Thailand. lf it rains very heavily for two days, it is very difficult to go through this road. I would like to ask the Minister if he will send more men to work on the Ulu Pandan scheme. If they are not working fast enough, they should work day and night.

    Just now the Minister said that there was not enough money to spend on all the flood alleviation projects. That is wrong. If there is no money, how can we build houses and flats? We should spend part of the money allocated to flat-building on the Ulu Pandan scheme, which is a very important project. The small drains in the area should be widened so that the water will flow more quickly to the sea. The East Coast Reclamation Scheme has somehow affected the free flow of water. Can the Minister take steps to remedy the situation?

    Mr Barker: Sir, that is the longest supplementary question I have ever heard! Perhaps to satisfy the Member for Ulu Pandan I should say, as I said in the last sitting of Parliament, that the

Ulu Pandan scheme has been delayed because of rock formation which has been encountered in the tunnels we are now building between Bukit Timah and Ulu Pandan.

    It is not the P.W.D. workers who are working on the project but the contractors. The work has been let out to three or four contractors under a tender scheme. Of course, if it rains, they cannot work. But I will look into the Member's complaint and see what can be done to expedite matters.

FLOODS
(Loss of lives and damage to property)


    6. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether investigations have been carried out to ascertain the loss and damage as a result of the recent floods; and whether he will inform the House of the number of lives lost and the extent of damage to property.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Sir, investigations have been carried out to ascertain the loss and damage caused by the floods of the 10th December, 1969. Preliminary figures show that the damage has been extensive. Five deaths were reported to have been caused by the very heavy rains and the subsequent flooding. Some 10,000 families were affected.

    Damage to private farms, properties, and household effects is believed to be substantial, but it is difficult to assess such losses with any degree of accuracy. In the public sector, the damage to buildings, roads, bridges, sewerage pumping stations and other installations is estimated to be $780,000, and to electricity, water and gas installations, about $500,000.

FLOODS
(Relief to victims)


    7. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Social Affairs what assistance has been given to help the people affected by the floods in order that they may rehabilitate themselves.

Column: 311



    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the floods, the Social Welfare Department opened five relief centres at:

    (i) Serangoon Secondary School;

    (ii) Geylang Serai Vocational School;

    (iii) Bedok School;

    (iv) Balestier Hill School; and

    (v) St. Andrew's School.

    It is estimated that 2,800 persons used these five centres. In addition, eight relief centres manned by voluntary workers were opened in various flood-stricken areas. These eight centres were used by an estimated 870 persons.

    The Social Welfare Department gave immediate relief on the day of the flood itself by supplying the following foodstuffs to the above 13 centres:

    (a) Rice;

    (b) Sugar;

    (c) Coffee powder;

    (d) Sardines;

    (e) Fresh vegetables;

    (f) Biscuits;

    (g) Ikan bilis; and

    (h) Dried prawns.

The total quantity of foodstuffs supplied came to 3,250 lbs. In addition, 3,780 lbs, of clothings were issued to those in need.

    After the floods, as an immediate measure, the Social Welfare Department paid cash grants at the rate of $10 per person to 12 families comprising 65 persons whose houses had been extensively damaged or rendered unsafe by the floods. Eight of these families have been allocated Housing and Development Board flats.

    The following categories of persons were adversely affected as a result of the floods:

    (i) Farmers;

    (ii) Next-of-kin and dependants of those who died;

    (iii) Persons who need alternative accommodation as a result of their houses being washed away, rendered unsafe or extensively damaged.

Column: 312



    The Government has drawn up a relief scheme for farms damaged by the floods to help the farmers re-establish their farms and get back to full production as quickly as possible. The scheme provides for aid in cash as well as in kind to farms licensed by the Primary Production Department.

    Small vegetable farmers have been given $100 in cash plus $50 worth of materials, i.e., vegetable seeds, fertilizers, insecticides, fungicides and lime. Farmers of medium-sized vegetable farms were given $100 in cash plus $100 worth of materials. Farmers of large-sized farms were given $100 in cash plus $150 worth of materials.

    Pig farmers are eligible for a loan of up to $1,000 at 3 per cent interest repayable in one year. In addition to this loan, small pig farmers who lost pigs in the floods are given $160 worth of feeding stuff.

    Poultry farmers are eligible for a loan of up to $500 at 3 per cent interest repayable in one year. In addition to this loan, small poultry farmers who lost poultry in the floods are given $150 worth of feeding stuff.

    It is estimated that this relief scheme for farmers will cost the Government $137,400 to be given in the form of grants and $406,500 by way of loans.

    The Government has also drawn up a scheme to assist the next-of-kin of those who died as a result of the floods. The scheme provides for the ex gratia payment of compensation from the General Relief Fund. Payment will be assessed on the lines of the Workmen's Compensation Ordinance which provides for maximum compensation of 36 months' wages or $7,200 whichever is the less. The estimated cost of ex gratia compensation is $20,360.

    The floods also rendered a number of persons homeless. Such persons who need alternative accommodation as a result of the floods will be paid a rent subsidy on the same basis as that paid to persons made homeless by fire, i.e., at the rate of $7 per person per month subject to a limit of $35 per

Column: 313

family per month for a maximum period of three months. The estimated cost for rent subsidies is $1,491.

AIR POLLUTION IN INDUSTRIAL
ESTATES
(Pilot survey)


    8. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Health if he will consider (a) undertaking immediately a pilot survey to determine the extent and degree of air pollution in Jurong and other selected industrial estates caused by noxious smoke, fumes, gases and dust from factories; (b) engaging an expert to carry out the survey; (c) making the report on the survey available to the House; (d) following up the pilot scheme with a complete survey of the problem of air pollution in the Republic; and (e) taking the necessary measures to eliminate air pollution as far as possible.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is aware of the increasing seriousness of the problem of air pollution especially in Jurong and other smaller industrial areas in Singapore. Further, the problem is enhanced by the increasing number of motor vehicles and other equipment utilising the internal combustion engine which can cause pollution of the atmosphere with the discharge of exhaust gases, especially carbon monoxide and sulphur dioxide, on the main highways of the city.

    Steps have already been taken for an expert on air pollution control from the World Health Organisation to be assigned to Singapore to help us look into this problem and to help in the development of an air pollution control section. Among the functions of the expert it is envisaged that he should -

    (1) initiate studies to assess the present position of air pollution and the extent of the problem in Singapore;

Column: 314



    (2) in pursuance of the first objective, to recommend the personnel and equipment necessary to set up a monitoring system, that is, a system for the measurement of the degree and extent of pollution;

    (3) to recommend such remedial and/or preventive measures as may be feasible and necessary to cope with the situation;
